title: Why You Need to Add a Luxury Train Journey to Your Bucket List
text:
Why You Need to Add a Luxury Train Journey to Your Bucket List Written by: Mia Taylor 09/08/15 - 8:53 AM EDT 
NEW YORK ( MainStreet ) â€” There's something about majestic, wide-open expanses, and pastoral landscapes that impacts even the most jaded and frenetic traveler. 
Maybe it's the reminder that there's more to life than big cities, big careers and the trappings of modern existence. 
And these days, when even vacationing involves multi-tasking, and busily checking off items on life's to-do list, while also constantly bragging about your latest feats on social media, there's no better way to break from the pack than hopping aboard a mode of transportation that dates back more than 100 years. More Headlines 5 Money-Saving Questions to Ask Your College Financial Aid Officer 
Even now, in the 2015, trains remain a meandering, time warp form of travel. And unlike planes that hurtle you from one part of the world to another through the clouds, and boats that mostly showcase ocean expanses, trains excel at displaying stunning scenery that's missed on other modes of transportation. 
I learned this lesson during a recent trip on the Rocky Mountaineer, a train that was built specifically to put Canada's remotest, most stunning scenery, including the Rocky Mountains, on full display. The largest, privately owned luxury train company in the world, the Rocky Mountaineer specializes in offering an experience that's become almost quaint or forgotten - sitting, relaxing and simply contemplating the scenery. That's the primary activity of the trip. There's no bungee jumping. No zip lining. No spas, casinos or speedboats. Read More: 8 Best Train Rides 
With its famous, glass domed cars, the Rocky Mountaineer is a visual journey punctuated by spotting a bear running along a creek, an eagle gliding through the air or spying a snow covered mountain peak in the distance. 
"It's the slowness of the train," says Rumit Mehta of Immersion Journeys of train travel. "You can sit there and watch the world go by. You go through these old towns established by farmers, and the landscape is stunning, which is hard to see when you're on a highway or flying. These luxury, slow-travel train journeys are from a bygone era when people dressed up to have dinner and high tea was in vogue." 
Which makes me wonder when the Scottish kilt and bagpipe tradition was added to the mix, because that's how my recent journey began. 1
